Award.AwardTitle: Genetic Influences on Parental Care and Parent-Offspring Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding the mechanism that regulated social behavior has implications across biology and from basic research to health related concerns. In mammals there is larger body of study on the critical role of the peptide oxytocin in the formation of social recognition and bonds. Here the researchers proposes to examine the insect equivalent, inotocin, to determine if it plays the same role in stimulate parenting and parent-offspring interactions in the subsocial beetle, Nicrophorus vespilloides. This insect has elaborate parental care, including direct regurgitation of food to begging babies, by both males and females. The genome of this beetle has recently been sequenced, and this provides the tools to identify genes that are predicted to play a role in social tolerance, parenting, and pair bonds. The proposed research tests three ideas: 1) genetic pathways can be predicted; 2) sex differences in parenting reflect turning on and off of different genes in the two sexes; 3) the same genes influence social interactions in both parents and their offspring. This research will lead to a greater understanding of the genetics underpinning difference in parenting and how genetics influences social interactions. Developing insect systems to understand genetic influences on social behavior can help identify of genetic problems may lead to asocial behavior, and provide a way to test possible solutions.

This research makes use of candidate gene screens, transcriptomics, and pharmacological manipulations to examine the extent to which genetic influences on social behavior can be and are common across species. A second goal is to examine how sex differences in parenting arise. Finally, if time and resources allow, the extent that social exchanges, such as parent-offspring interactions, involve pleiotropy will be examined. Genes are predicted based on known functions in pathways that are predicted to have been coopted behaviors involved in the evolution of parental care. For example, parenting is predicted to involve a change in mating, aggression and feeding and so genes with known functions in these pathways should also be involved in parenting. This further suggests that genes involved in parenting will be taxonomically independent. Gene expression patterns will be examined in neural tissue from individuals that are not yet parenting, actively parenting beetles, and those that have completed parenting. Patterns of expression will be evaluated with qRT-PCR. Confirmation of the function of genes with significant changes in expression will involve either pharmacological manipulations or RNAi. Sex differences in parenting have been identified with transcrioptomic studies, and these will be verified using qRT-PCR. Gene expression in larvae that are begging and receiving parenting will be examined to test the hypothesis that the same genes involved in parenting are involved in soliciting parenting. In addition to testing these hypotheses, this research provides novel genetic resources for the research community: It also identifies genetic influences on social interactions in a novel context, examining the generality of function of genes influencing social interactions. Finally, this research facilitates comparisons between organisms with increasingly complex parental care and social behavior. In terms of broader impacts, the research will focus on developing human resources of both undergraduate and postgraduate researchers, and develop international collaborations involving students at all stages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
IOS-1354358 ($635,000; September 2014 - August 2018) was the sole grant supporting our laboratory during this period. Our goal was to identify gene with expression associated with direct interactions between parents and offspring and test the hypothesis that specific genes could be predicted based on likely evolutionary precursor behaviors to parenting. We predicted and found that the expression of genes associated with feeding, energy, immunity and social neuropeptides differ between caring and non-caring individuals. All of the work has now been published or is in press resulting in 27 papers on burying beetles, genetics, and evolution of parental care acknowledging this grant and a total of 39 papers and one book chapter published 2015-2019. We are now poised for functional genetic studies, with the implication of understanding how social interactions are directly influenced by genetics.

We first sequenced, assembled, annotated and made publicly available the genome of the burying beetle Nicrophorus vespilloides. An unanticipated outcome was that our sequencing uncovered the first demonstration of cytosine methylation in beetles. We hypothesized that methylation would be more associated with insects with social interactions and tested this in a phylogenetic context. This hypothesis turned out to be wrong – methylation, where it occurs in insects, shows no phylogenetic or social pattern and does not influence behavioral plasticity in N. vespilloides. The role of methylation in insects remains mysterious.

With the genome in hand, we tested our a-priori hypotheses regarding gene expression and parenting. We first showed that gene expression in caring males and females overlaps, supporting a role for specific genes during care. We next investigated specific candidate genes. We had predicted genes influencing reproduction would be co-opted for parenting and found that vitellogenin expression in the head is associated with parenting in both males and female. Specific neuropeptides, particularly those associated with feeding circuits and social interactions, are associated with a shift to parenting in N. vespilloides. Neuropeptides are the main causes of quantitative variation within parenting. We predicted apoLp-III, would be differentially expressed in the brain because of its homology with apoE in humans. We found this gene expression reflected energy use and differed between males and females, with similar expression of apoLp-III in pre-hatching parental activities but greater changes in females during post-hatching care. In addition, we found little overlap in the genes involved in a transition to care from a non-caring state and the genes associated with continuous variation in the level of care provided, consistent with the hypothesis that the processes involved in origins of care are likely to be very different to those involved in the maintenance of care. This begins to reconcile studies based on gross differences (populations, species, inbred lines) or changes in state (not parenting to parenting) and the subtle variation within a behavior state typically addressed by quantitative geneticists looking at continuous variation. We reviewed the state of both molecular and statistical genetic influences on parenting in a book chapter for an upcoming book on genes and behavior.

In phenotypic studies, we found species differences in parenting and maternal effects, and that parenting is obligate and biparental care predominant in N. orbicollis unlike N. vespilloides where care is facultative and typically uniparental. We investigated the function of variation in larval mandibles. We published a model of how indirect genetic and maternal effects can influence the evolution of endothermy. Finally, with collaborators in the UK, we investigated indirect genetic effects and intraspecific and sexual competition on parental care, mating and aggression.

A major proposed broader impact was training of STEM students from undergraduates to postdoctoral scientists, with a focus on underrepresented groups. Chris Cunningham (postdoc), Eileen Roy-Zokan (postdoc), and Elizabeth McKinney (research scientist) were directly supported on the grant. Roy-Zokan has taken up a second postdoc. Cunningham is in a tenure-track position at the University of Swansea (UK). The grant supported work by PhD student Kyle Benowitz and Michelle Ziadie (NSF GRFP; URM). Benowitz received his PhD in 2018 and is now a postdoc at the University of Arizona. Ziadie is entering her final year of her PhD. Elijah Mehlferber (2015), Chimaka Ohanu (2016) and Felicia Obot-Ojong (2017) were REU students; Mehlferber and Obot-Ojong both co-authored publications, as did other undergraduate students Katherine Moody, Lauren Heeb, Daven Khana, Katie VanDenHeuvel, Mary Douthit, Madeline Sparks, and Ashley Amukamara. Eighteen undergraduates have pursued research projects supported by the funding of this grant, of which 13 were female and 5 URM. The grant supported the international travel and collaboration of Kyle Benowitz with Mike Ritchie in Scotland.

 

The other proposed broader impact was to produce genomic resources for the field. We have made publicly available transcriptomes of both N. vespilloides and N. orbicollis, the genome transcriptomes and corresponding methylomes, and a metabolome of N. vespilloides.
